text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Science Fiction Chronicle is a major science fiction and fantasy news magazine distributed by Algal Press, which appears monthly. Its publisher is Andrew Porter, who for most of his life has been a science fiction fan. Porter told us how he discovered science fiction. It's a story familiar to most of us. My brother was reading SF first. He's five years older than I am. So when he was 15 and I was 10, I just started picking it up from him. And he still reads SF, but obviously I have gone much further, much deeper into the subject than he would have ever dreamed of. Porter went on to produce several fan publications, then he started Algal Magazine. Algal was later named Starship, which is still a viable magazine. Porter founded Algal Press when his ambitions grew. Science Fiction Chronicle is another one of the productions of Algal Press. We asked him who else is involved in running Algal Press. When I started, wanted to start publishing chapbooks and books and stuff like that, I adopted the name Algal Press from Algal Magazine. But it's not really a... It's just sort of like the name I press, and if I do chapbooks or books or something... I mean, I did one book, really. I did the Book of Ellison, which is a real hardcover and a trade paperback. But people think it's... I work for this vast Algal Press. And of course, also the appearance of Starship and Chronicle, like, wow, typeset. And Starship has, or at least had, four-color covers. Wow, he's got this vast organization behind him. He's not a fan at all, they say. It's just all me, pasting stuff up in my living room. After having published several fanzines, Porter started Science Fiction Chronicle. It was the magazine he had always dreamed of doing. So for years, I carried on my business card... You have a business card that impresses people and costs five bucks or five thousand. And I had a thing called SF Chronicle listed in there, you know, which was just a title. And it was like the newsie I always wanted to do. Finally, in 1979, I started as a news section in Ellgo, which at that time had become Starship by then, changed the title. More hardcore SF title. And it started out with, you know, getting subscriptions. So in other words, I actually started it with several hundred subscriptions. And it was just a thing done the way I wanted to do it, like typeset and nicely laid out, stuff like that. Science Fiction Chronicle just had its fourth birthday. It's a rarity for a science fiction news magazine to have survived for so long. Through the years, various people have started out news zines. And they've all folded. They've all gone away. They've all stopped publishing. And people got tired or they got tired of losing money or something. And it didn't. It's still here. It's doing pretty well. I mean, it's not... I don't think it's making money yet. But it's at the break-even point, which is always nice. Advertising is increasing. Now the recession is ending. Things are starting to take off. Why would a fan devote his life to producing a news magazine such as Science Fiction Chronicle, especially since it doesn't net him much profit? Porter told us his reasons. I've always loved science fiction. I mean, I could probably make a lot more money publishing a magazine with a lot of naked people in it. Or, you know, or something, motorcycles or, you know, Hells Angels official newsletter or something like that. You know, if you don't buy this newsletter, it will kill you. One of those things. I don't know. But I just love science fiction. I've always loved science fiction. And if I can make my living doing something in science fiction, that's great. Porter also gets a kick out of producing Science Fiction Chronicle. The kick really is getting up when I feel like it and working until when I feel like it and not having a boss to yell at me and say, you screwed up. Or I screwed up and you're going to take the blame because I'm your boss. We'll have more on our next show with publisher Andrew Porter. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Darrell Lane. And Bill Vernon. Algal Press is a one-man operation which publishes the magazine Starship, an occasional book, and the monthly trade newspaper Science Fiction Chronicle. Andrew Porter of Brooklyn is the one-man operator. He handles all aspects of the business, from subscriptions to advertising, from editorializing to arranging the printing. Recently we spoke with Porter, and we asked him to describe a typical work day. I get up anywhere from about 10.30 to 11.30, and putter around, and I'll do stuff in the morning like entering financial stuff or getting checks ready for deposit and, say, go into Midtown. And I hit a whole bunch of stuff in one stop on the subway. There's my commercial bank for my accounts, you know, Starship and SF Chronicle and stuff. And then two doors away there's my personal savings bank. Across the street is the New York office of the printer I use. And I can go in there and use their tie line to co-op the printer out in Pennsylvania and find out how stuff's doing. Or I can deliver stuff that has to be, you know, they have a pouch system overnight. There's a stationery store near there I use, and my post office box is up there in Grand Central Station and the place where I have pictures developed and all that. And, you know, then I come back home and I'll do other stuff at night. I like to work late at night, very quiet. I have a TV going, some background noise. I watch Johnny Carson, and then David Letterman comes on. And then after that there's a very good news program called News Overnight on NBC, which is very tongue-in-cheek. They do a lot, not ready for primetime news and other strange things. And then if I'm really working straight through, there's two issues, two episodes of Mary Tyler Moore come on. It's followed by an episode of Bob Newhart. And by that time, it's four in the morning, and then I love to see a rerun come on. Usually I can't stand that at all, so I just turn off my feet. Or I'll knock off the door earlier and then read. The April 1983 issue of Science Fiction Chronicle had some startling headlines. Cherry, Spinred, to Wed, Collaborate. Dahl pays $50 million for New American Library. The New England Science Fiction Association acquires Sheraton Boston. These turned out to be fictitious. They were an April Fool's joke. Porter told us about it. I asked people's permission to do that. I asked Don Warren's permission to do that story. And I asked Cherry's permission, and I asked Spinred's. And I arranged this sort of a matchmaker thing. I was saying, well, who would you like to get married to? And Cherry didn't mind Spinred, and Spinred didn't mind Cherry. And I ran those stories. And a heck of a lot of people believe those stories. I understand that various writers were calling other writers out and reading the issues over the phone and stuff. And people who knew Spinred knew he was planning to move out of New York. If you slide down, you're going to move to Oklahoma, not Los Angeles. And if it's set in sight, people believe it. Porter promised there will be a special treat to appear in the April of 1984 issue of Science Fiction Chronicle. For next April, I have two ideas I'm going to use. And this one was kind of funny and humorous, like the thing with the New England Science Fiction Association buying a shirt in Boston. And I have two ideas I'm going to use. And one is going to be either, I won't tell you what they are, the specific ideas, but one will either be kind of interesting and humorous, or the other might be horrifying, and I think will scare the hell out of a lot of people. And it won't be humorous, but it's going to be possible. It's going to be a possible story, but it's going to scare a lot of people, and I think it might anger a lot of people, too. But it'll be interesting. It'll be a hope. More with Andrew Porter on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Oh, my God. I'm so thankful for you. Oh, my God. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. the overall magazine. Mailing costs are higher because it weighs more. So what I did the last issue, I went from a four-color cover to a two-color cover. And I think it looks good. It doesn't look like it. I've seen other people do two colors and they do well. The artwork is in blue and then the pie is in black. So I'm using it like that. So not having a four-color cover I saved about $300 in cost of color separation and another $400 or $500 in the printing. Porter told us there's still another tactic for saving on the cost of production. Remember, these strategies allow him to continue producing Starship. This new issue, I'm not going to have a cover. It's going to be a stealth cover, but it's going to be the outside form for the printing that's going to be two colors. So it'll have an effective two-color cover. But not having that cover and just printing it sort of on the run. Actually, what I might do is I run the outside form on slick paper. So it'll be like eight pages of slick paper in the front, eight pages in the back, and then uncoated the rest of it. And that'll save, with the cost of having a chrome coat cover and stuff, that'll save $900. And how many copies you have to sell to make back that $900. So, and also, it's gone twice a year now. And, um, so it's basically the difference between doing something that'll make a small profit and something that'll lose. And you can't publish something that's going to lose money. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Thank you. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Ardeth Mayhar hit the fantasy scene in 1979 with several novels. Since Mayhar has a self-admitted penchant for using at least one unpronounceable word in each title, will let her tell you what she's written in the fantasy and science fiction genres? In 1979, Doubleday published How the Gods Wole in Kiranok. In 80, Doubleday brought out The Seekers of Sharnung. In 81, 81 brought Soul Singer of Tearno from Athenaeum. 82, Busted Loose Like a Pot of Popcorn. Warlock's Gift came from Doubleday in the spring. Paperback reprints from Ace of How the Gods Wole in Seekers of Sharnung came out that spring. Bruise of the Liar came out from Athenaeum that fall. And Golden Dream, A Fuzzy Odyssey came out. That's all. So it sort of just grabbed you up like a tornado and carried you away spinning. We asked Mayhar what type of fantasy she writes. It is really more towards heroic fantasy. Though not in the sword and sorcery type of thing. These are more people who are heroic, not through physical strength or anything like that, but because of the press of circumstance and integrity. I try to write about the way people can be and often are. Real urban is fine. I mean, there's a place for that. But I have never seen that the cause of human enlightenment has been forwarded too much by depicting the absolute worst aspects of human nature. People can be noble. They can be courageous. And they very often are, so why not write about it? Since she is a poet as well, we asked Mayhar if writing poetry helps her write prose. I talk to a lot of college classes, and I belong to a group that has beginners in it. And I tell them, write poetry even if it's bad poetry, because in poetry you don't have a novel's worth of elbow room. You can't use 25 wrong words to get across an idea that two perfect words will give with punch, you know, with real impact. Poetry takes the laziness out of it. It makes you search for the proper words, the proper phrases, exact construction. It conveys what you want to give. Mayhar published her first novel after her children have come. We asked her if she ever wishes she had gotten published earlier. You know, I have given that a lot of thought. It's a very rough road to hold. But I have come to the conclusion that people who have a great deal of success, they're young, quite often don't keep pushing themselves to refine their technique, get better and better and better, so that, by golly, you are so good they can't turn you down. Besides which, you know, when you live 40 years, you know a lot of things you didn't know when you lived 25 years. You understand not only what people do, but how they feel under different circumstances. When a husband comes home and he's lost his job, you not only know how he acts, you know how he and his wife feel about it. And this is something that I think causes a great deal of modern non-genre fiction to be superficial. People are writing about it who have never stood in those shoes and who don't really understand what it does to your gut to have a child get deathly ill at 2 o'clock in the morning. You know, all this sort of thing. We'll have more with Ardeth Mayhar on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Studies at that primera, Studies at this Supervisional Blockchain, collectors, and friends of mine and her bunch of things to use. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Ardeth Mayhar is an East Texas writer who recently began publishing in a variety of genres. She has written several fantasy novels and one science fiction novel, that being a continuation of the Fuzzy series started by the late H. Bean Piper. Mayhar's contribution to that series is entitled Golden Dream, a Fuzzy Odyssey. Mayhar has written some westerns and she's working in other genres. She manages to write a lot because she works so rapidly. This is amazing because she lives on a farm and she has a lot of chores to do each day. We asked Mayhar to describe a typical day. My husband and I get up at six. He has to go to town and open up his service day. So I get up and fix breakfast for him at six. And at 8.15 comes the postman. So I'm standing there. I'm washing dishes or I'm out there milking the cow and I'm listening for the postman. You know when Snoopy is a vulture, when he's on top of his doghouse being a vulture, that's the way I am with the postman. I milked one of the cows and turned the five calves in on her and her partner and then feed the goats and feed the cats and feed the dogs. Then I get the mail and look through. And I get this interesting mail. A lot of days I begin my real work. Of course, in among this, I usually try to sweep the porch and straighten the stacks. I've discovered you don't have to clean your living room if you keep your stacks straight. So I straighten the stacks. Then I hit the typewriter about nine o'clock usually. And I may answer six letters before I start writing. But then I will usually write, depending on what I am engaged in, from three to seven hours. I can write a pretty fair-sized short story in two and a half, three hours. But if I'm working on a book and it's really hot, well, I'll go right on to it until 3.30 or 4 o'clock sometimes. And I'm one of these lucky people. I don't have to eat. I don't need to eat. So I don't get hungry. I don't have to interrupt myself. And about 3.30 or 4, though, the goat starts yelling out the pen. I don't know why she yells at 4 o'clock. But she usually does. And that wakes me up. And I think, you know, I don't know whether I can get my old bones up from here or not. I'd better try and see, you know. Among much creaking and groaning, I point myself off the stool and straighten out and uncrink the back. And so that's then when I go out and, oh, I may dig in my garden or take a walk up our little road. It's time to get back. It's time to lick the cat all over again and milk the cows and put the calves on and feed the goats and all that good stuff. And then it's time to go supper for Papa. And he gets home about 6.30. And so we're pretty well ready to pack it in. So Mayhar's farm chores take up a great deal of her day. We wondered if she might be more productive if she were to live in the city. I am a peasant to my toenate. I am not happy. I have lived in town periodically and have been miserable every minute. Oh, I had to live in Houston for 16 months. I thought I'd die. In fact, I think I would have died if we hadn't left. We've always had a little plot of ground. Maybe not for two acres, but something. We've always had some kind of livestock. When spring comes, if I can't get my hands in the dirt and make a garden, you just better buy a straight jacket and call the men in the white coats because I'm ready to go off. I do my best writing, thinking in the garden. Or even milking the cow. You know, the old head just keeps rolling right along. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the remaining prosperous pictures. There is good air sauce. Here is a message for the capture budget it. I have Miltontı, agencyffentlich. Well, it is secure. I believe there is still O did. Thegency attack is Christ. I have a decent farm but I just have�ité. I hope it works for the differentarians. This is 추가 A video from Ben idea. I have obviamente the majority of our people. Thank you.

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane.
Science Fiction Chronicle is a major science fiction and fantasy news magazine distributed by Algal Press, which appears monthly.
Its publisher is Andrew Porter, who for most of his life has been a science fiction fan.
Porter told us how he discovered science fiction. It's a story familiar to most of us.
My brother was reading SF first. He's five years older than I am.
So when he was 15 and I was 10, I just started picking it up from him.
And he still reads SF, but obviously I have gone much further, much deeper into the subject than he would have ever dreamed of.
Porter went on to produce several fan publications, then he started Algal Magazine.
Algal was later named Starship, which is still a viable magazine.
Porter founded Algal Press when his ambitions grew.
Science Fiction Chronicle is another one of the productions of Algal Press.
We asked him who else is involved in running Algal Press.
When I started, wanted to start publishing chapbooks and books and stuff like that, I adopted the name Algal Press from Algal Magazine.
But it's not really a...
It's just sort of like the name I press, and if I do chapbooks or books or something...
I mean, I did one book, really.
I did the Book of Ellison, which is a real hardcover and a trade paperback.
But people think it's...
I work for this vast Algal Press.
And of course, also the appearance of Starship and Chronicle, like, wow, typeset.
And Starship has, or at least had, four-color covers.
Wow, he's got this vast organization behind him.
He's not a fan at all, they say.
It's just all me, pasting stuff up in my living room.
After having published several fanzines, Porter started Science Fiction Chronicle.
It was the magazine he had always dreamed of doing.
So for years, I carried on my business card...
You have a business card that impresses people and costs five bucks or five thousand.
And I had a thing called SF Chronicle listed in there, you know, which was just a title.
And it was like the newsie I always wanted to do.
Finally, in 1979, I started as a news section in Ellgo,
which at that time had become Starship by then, changed the title.
More hardcore SF title.
And it started out with, you know, getting subscriptions.
So in other words, I actually started it with several hundred subscriptions.
And it was just a thing done the way I wanted to do it, like typeset and nicely laid out, stuff like that.
Science Fiction Chronicle just had its fourth birthday.
It's a rarity for a science fiction news magazine to have survived for so long.
Through the years, various people have started out news zines.
And they've all folded.
They've all gone away.
They've all stopped publishing.
And people got tired or they got tired of losing money or something.
And it didn't.
It's still here.
It's doing pretty well.
I mean, it's not...
I don't think it's making money yet.
But it's at the break-even point, which is always nice.
Advertising is increasing.
Now the recession is ending.
Things are starting to take off.
Why would a fan devote his life to producing a news magazine such as Science Fiction Chronicle,
especially since it doesn't net him much profit?
Porter told us his reasons.
I've always loved science fiction.
I mean, I could probably make a lot more money publishing a magazine with a lot of naked people in it.
Or, you know, or something, motorcycles or, you know, Hells Angels official newsletter or something like that.
You know, if you don't buy this newsletter, it will kill you.
One of those things.
I don't know.
But I just love science fiction.
I've always loved science fiction.
And if I can make my living doing something in science fiction, that's great.
Porter also gets a kick out of producing Science Fiction Chronicle.
The kick really is getting up when I feel like it and working until when I feel like it and not having a boss to yell at me and say,
you screwed up.
Or I screwed up and you're going to take the blame because I'm your boss.
We'll have more on our next show with publisher Andrew Porter.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show.

And people who knew Spinred knew he was planning to move out of New York.
If you slide down, you're going to move to Oklahoma, not Los Angeles.
And if it's set in sight, people believe it.

For next April, I have two ideas I'm going to use.
And this one was kind of funny and humorous, like the thing with the New England Science Fiction Association buying a shirt in Boston.
And I have two ideas I'm going to use.
And one is going to be either, I won't tell you what they are, the specific ideas,
but one will either be kind of interesting and humorous,
or the other might be horrifying, and I think will scare the hell out of a lot of people.
And it won't be humorous, but it's going to be possible.
It's going to be a possible story, but it's going to scare a lot of people,
and I think it might anger a lot of people, too.
But it'll be interesting. It'll be a hope.
More with Andrew Porter on our next show.

It is really more towards heroic fantasy.

I talk to a lot of college classes,
and I belong to a group that has beginners in it.

write poetry even if it's bad poetry,

they're young,
quite often don't keep pushing themselves to refine their technique,
get better and better and better,

Besides which, you know,
when you live 40 years,
you know a lot of things you didn't know when you lived 25 years.
You understand not only what people do,
but how they feel under different circumstances.
When a husband comes home and he's lost his job,
you not only know how he acts,
you know how he and his wife feel about it.
And this is something that I think causes a great deal of modern non-genre fiction
to be superficial.
People are writing about it who have never stood in those shoes
and who don't really understand what it does to your gut
to have a child get deathly ill at 2 o'clock in the morning.
You know, all this sort of thing.

Ardeth Mayhar is an East Texas writer who recently began publishing in a variety of genres.
She has written several fantasy novels and one science fiction novel, that being a continuation of the Fuzzy series started by the late H. Bean Piper.
Mayhar's contribution to that series is entitled Golden Dream, a Fuzzy Odyssey.
Mayhar has written some westerns and she's working in other genres.
She manages to write a lot because she works so rapidly.
This is amazing because she lives on a farm and she has a lot of chores to do each day.
We asked Mayhar to describe a typical day.
My husband and I get up at six. He has to go to town and open up his service day.
So I get up and fix breakfast for him at six.
And at 8.15 comes the postman.
So I'm standing there. I'm washing dishes or I'm out there milking the cow and I'm listening for the postman.
You know when Snoopy is a vulture, when he's on top of his doghouse being a vulture, that's the way I am with the postman.
I milked one of the cows and turned the five calves in on her and her partner and then feed the goats and feed the cats and feed the dogs.
Then I get the mail and look through.
And I get this interesting mail.
A lot of days I begin my real work.
Of course, in among this, I usually try to sweep the porch and straighten the stacks.
I've discovered you don't have to clean your living room if you keep your stacks straight.
So I straighten the stacks.
Then I hit the typewriter about nine o'clock usually.
And I may answer six letters before I start writing.
But then I will usually write, depending on what I am engaged in, from three to seven hours.
I can write a pretty fair-sized short story in two and a half, three hours.
But if I'm working on a book and it's really hot, well, I'll go right on to it until 3.30 or 4 o'clock sometimes.
And I'm one of these lucky people.
I don't have to eat.
I don't need to eat.
So I don't get hungry.
I don't have to interrupt myself.
And about 3.30 or 4, though, the goat starts yelling out the pen.
I don't know why she yells at 4 o'clock.
But she usually does.
And that wakes me up.
And I think, you know, I don't know whether I can get my old bones up from here or not.
I'd better try and see, you know.
Among much creaking and groaning, I point myself off the stool and straighten out and uncrink the back.
And so that's then when I go out and, oh, I may dig in my garden or take a walk up our little road.
It's time to get back.
It's time to lick the cat all over again and milk the cows and put the calves on and feed the goats and all that good stuff.
And then it's time to go supper for Papa.
And he gets home about 6.30.
And so we're pretty well ready to pack it in.
So Mayhar's farm chores take up a great deal of her day.
We wondered if she might be more productive if she were to live in the city.
I am a peasant to my toenate.
I am not happy.

Oh, I had to live in Houston for 16 months.
I thought I'd die.

We've always had a little plot of ground.
Maybe not for two acres, but something.
We've always had some kind of livestock.
When spring comes, if I can't get my hands in the dirt and make a garden,
you just better buy a straight jacket and call the men in the white coats because I'm ready to go off.
I do my best writing, thinking in the garden.
Or even milking the cow.
You know, the old head just keeps rolling right along.
